title: 115_hr2185
content: The Act is titled the "Iran Sanctions Relief Review Act" and involves determining if foreign financial institutions have facilitated transactions for covered persons. The "Iran Sanctions Relief Review Act" requires the President to assess foreign financial institutions' involvement in facilitating transactions for covered persons every 180 days for up to 5 years. The findings are to be reported to congressional committees. The "Iran Sanctions Relief Review Act" mandates the President to certify determinations regarding foreign financial institutions, including Iranian ones, to congressional committees. Certifications must be in unclassified form but may include a classified annex. Transactions and financial services are deemed significant based on regulations in title 31, Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 3. Determination and certification of whether certain foreign persons have supported covered persons. The President must determine if foreign persons listed in Attachments 3 or 4 of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action have supported covered persons and report to congressional committees every 180 days for up to 5 years. The President must certify determinations regarding foreign persons supporting covered individuals to congressional committees every 180 days for up to 5 years in unclassified form, with the option of a classified annex. SEC. 4. COVERED PERSONS. A person described in this section is an organization designated as a foreign terrorist organization by the Secretary of State or a foreign person whose property or interests are blocked under Executive Order 13224 or Executive Order 13382. Executive Orders related to blocking property and proliferation of weapons of mass destruction include Executive Order 13382, Executive Order 13094, Executive Order 12938, and Executive Order 13338. Executive Orders related to blocking property in connection with the national emergency with respect to Syria include Executive Order 13399, Executive Order 13460, and Executive Order 13572, which address the prohibition of certain goods and human rights abuses in Syria. Executive Orders related to blocking property in connection with the national emergency in Syria include Executive Orders 13573, 13582, and 13608, which prohibit certain transactions and entry into the United States for foreign sanctions evaders in Iran and Syria. Executive Orders 13573, 13582, and 13608 block property and entry into the US for foreign sanctions evaders in Iran and Syria, including those involved in grave human rights abuses. The International Emergency Economic Powers Act blocks property of individuals associated with Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps or its affiliates. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "appropriate congressional committees" refers to those defined in the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996. "Foreign financial institution" is defined as per section 1010.605 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations. "Foreign person" includes natural persons who are not U.S. citizens, as well as corporations and partnerships. A foreign terrorist organization is defined as any designated organization that is not a U.S. person or a representative of a foreign government. It does not include foreign financial institutions as described in section 2(b). The term "terrorist organization" refers to any organization designated by the Secretary of State as a foreign terrorist organization. The term "Iranian financial institution" is defined as per the Comprehensive Iran Sanctions, Accountability, and Divestment Act of 2010. The "Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action" refers to the agreement made by Iran and others in Vienna on July 14, 2015. The Plan of Action was agreed upon in Vienna on July 14, 2015, by Iran and several other countries, and was transmitted to Congress on July 19, 2015. The terms "person" and "United States person" are defined in section 14 of the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996.
